dt: {bc}to assist a celebrant as {a_link|server} at mass

dt.t: in a day when few people could write, seals {it}served{/it} as signatures

dt: {bc}to be worthy of reliance or trust
{bc}to hold an office {bc}discharge a duty or function
{bc}to help persons to food: such as
{bc}to set out portions of food or drink
{bc}to put the ball or shuttlecock in play in various games (such as tennis, volleyball, or badminton)
{bc}to give the service and respect due to (a superior)
{bc}to comply with the commands or demands of {bc}{sx|gratify||}
{bc}to give military or naval service to
{bc}to perform the duties of (an office or post)
{bc}to pay a lover's or suitor's court to (a lady)

dt.t: that gentle lady, whom I love and {wi}serve{/wi}

dt: {bc}to furnish or supply with something needed or desired
{bc}to wait on (a customer) in a store
{bc}to treat or act toward in a specified way
{bc}to bring to notice, deliver, or execute as required by law
{bc}to make legal service upon (a person named in a process)
{bc}to wind yarn or wire tightly around (a rope or stay) for protection
{bc}to put (the ball or shuttlecock) in play (as in tennis, volleyball, or badminton)

et: Middle English {it}serven, sarven{/it} "to perform a duty, be employed, assume the role of personal attendant, be of use (of a body part), perform religious rites, provide food and drink (to people at a table), deliver (a legal writ)," borrowed from Anglo-French & Medieval Latin; Anglo-French {it}servir,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}serviō, servīre,{/it} going back to Latin, "to perform duties for (a master) in the capacity of a slave, act in subservience, be at the service of," verbal derivative of {it}servus{/it} "slave," perhaps, if the original sense was "watcher (of flocks), guardian," derivative with the nominal suffix {it}*-u̯o-,{/it} of the Indo-European verbal base {it}ser-{/it} "keep watch on, guard," whence, with varying ablaut and derivation, Greek (Homeric) {it}epì…órontai{/it} "they kept watch over," Greek {it}éphoros{/it} "watcher, overseer," {it}phrourós{/it} "guard, watchman" (< {it}*pro-horós{/it}), {it}phrourā{/it}́ "guard duty," Avestan {it}nišhauruuaiti{/it} "(s/he) keeps watch on" (from a stem {it}*har-u̯a-{/it}), {it}pasuš.hauruua{/it} "guarding the flock (of a dog)," {it}harətar-{/it} "watcher, guardian"

The above etymology of Latin {it}servus{/it} "slave" is carefully argued by Helmut Rix ({it}Die Termini der Unfreiheit in den Sprachen Alt-Italiens,{/it} Stuttgart, 1994, pp. 54-88), who rejects claims that the word is of Etruscan origin. Rix hypothesizes that between about 700 {sc}b.c.{/sc} and 450 {sc}b.c.{/sc}, as most transhumant shepherds in the Italian peninsula came to be slaves, an agent noun meaning "flock guard" developed a secondary sense "slave," and by the time of the earliest Latin texts had largely lost its original meaning (with {it}pāstor{/it} becoming the usual word for a shepherd—see {et_link|pastor:1|pastor:1}). The presumption is that Italic languages—as Indo-European languages generally—lacked a word for "slave," as slavery was an institution endemic to older Mediterranean and Middle Eastern civilizations. Note that Umbrian has a verb exemplified by the imperative {it}seritu{/it} "(let him/her) protect!" that corresponds in form but not in sense to Latin {it}servīre,{/it} which had been repurposed to reflect the new meaning of the noun {it}*seru̯os.{/it} Rix hypothesizes that the Latin verb {it}servāre{/it} "to watch over, look after" originally meant exclusively "to watch (the skies for an omen)," as a derivative of a noun {it}*seru̯ā{/it} or {it}*seru̯om{/it} "observation (of the skies)," and suggests that its senses expanded to cover those formerly held by the repurposed verb {it}servīre.{/it}
shortdef: to do military or naval service
to assist a celebrant as server at mass

dt: {bc}the act or action of putting the ball or shuttlecock in play in various games (such as volleyball, badminton, or tennis)

shortdef: the act or action of putting the ball or shuttlecock in play in various games (such as volleyball, badminton, or tennis); also : a turn to serve

dt: used to say that someone who has behaved badly deserves a particular punishment, problem, etc.

dt.t: "I hear his wife is divorcing him." "{it}It serves him right{/it} after the way he's treated her."
"He won't even talk to me." " {it}Serves you right{/it} for lying to him."

shortdef: —used to say that someone who has behaved badly deserves a particular punishment, problem, etc.

stems: if my memory serves me correctly
if my memory serves me right
if my memory serves me rightly

dt.t: The child's name was Rebecca Rose, {it}if memory serves{/it}. She and her mother both died in the big influenza epidemic of 1918.
It was on the third day, {it}if my memory serves me right{/it}, that I saw the lad killed.
He stated with hesitation that "{it}If my memory serves me correctly{/it}, his name was John."

dt: {bc}a smooth semisolid ice cream that contains less milk fat than regular ice cream and is made in and dispensed from a freezer in which it is aerated and continuously churned

shortdef: a smooth semisolid ice cream that contains less milk fat than regular ice cream and is made in and dispensed from a freezer in which it is aerated and continuously churned —often used before another noun

dt: {bc}to complete (a term in office, a prison sentence, etc.)

dt.t: He was unable to {it}serve out{/it} his five-year term as chairperson.
She was allowed to {it}serve out{/it} her sentence in a prison close to home.

shortdef: to complete (a term in office, a prison sentence, etc.)

dt: {bc}to give (food) to someone at a meal, in a restaurant, etc.

dt.t: That little restaurant {it}serves up{/it} some of the best Indian food in the city.
The movie {it}serves up{/it} a lot of laughs.

shortdef: to give (food) to someone at a meal, in a restaurant, etc. —sometimes used figuratively
